title: Nested Loops (Loops Within Loops)
simplifierConcept:
Imagine you're organizing a tournament where every team plays every other team:

• Outer loop: Go through each team (Team A, Team B, Team C...)
• Inner loop: For THIS team, play against every OTHER team

Team A plays Team B, Team C, Team D...
Team B plays Team A, Team C, Team D...
And so on!

That's a NESTED LOOP - a loop INSIDE another loop!

Think of it like checking every seat in a theater:
• Outer loop: Go through each ROW (Row 1, Row 2, Row 3...)
• Inner loop: For THIS row, check each SEAT (Seat A, B, C...)

Row 1, Seat A → Row 1, Seat B → ... → Row 2, Seat A → Row 2, Seat B...

Nested loops are powerful for grids, patterns, tables, or any time you need to do something for EVERY COMBINATION of two things!

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: The outer loop runs ONCE per full cycle. If it runs 5 times, you get 5 'groups' or 'rows' of inner loop executions.
The inner loop runs COMPLETELY for EACH iteration of the outer loop! If outer runs 3 times and inner runs 4 times, inner executes 3×4 = 12 times total!
Outer starts → Inner runs ALL its iterations → Outer increments → Inner runs ALL its iterations again → Repeat
Use different variable names! Common pattern: i for outer, j for inner. Or use meaningful names: row/col, x/y, etc.

challenge.instructions:
Create a times table! Generate a 5×5 multiplication grid.

1. Outer loop: row from 1 to 5
2. Inner loop: col from 1 to 5
3. For each combination, display: '[row] x [col] = [result]'

Bonus: Add a blank line between each 'row' of the table for readability!
challenge.hint: Structure: for (row) { for (col) { inner code } }. The inner loop runs completely for EACH value of the outer loop!
commonStickingPoints: Using same variable name: for (int i...) { for (int i...) } is WRONG! Inner loop needs a different name: j, col, y, etc.
Misunderstanding iteration count: If outer runs 3 times and inner runs 4 times, inner executes 12 times total, not 7!
Console.WriteLine vs Write: Use Write to print on same line, WriteLine to start a new line. Useful for patterns!
Performance warning: Nested loops can get SLOW fast! 3 nested loops with 100 iterations each = 1,000,000 operations!
